comment._content: I'll bet Dublin Zoo could tell you more, including the name of the cat! Lovely image, Mr Flood looks like he would prefer to leave the cat down soon!!!

comment.author: 26504183@N07
comment._content: what a great picture .. i love looking what they used to wear .. when you first see Mr Flood he looks quite smart don't you think? till you study his clothes and they are all filthy

comment.author: 47290943@N03
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/int0lerant] Got Mr Flood's name from the Irish Independent - that's where the photo originally appeared.

comment.author: 39191857@N05
comment._content: toypincher his clothes are not filthy - they're work worn from working with and handling animals all day every day.  He has probably changed into the bib-and-brace overalls and jacket from the suit that goes with that collar and tie!  Not much point in wearing your best suit with a wee kitten like that liable to rip them to shreds in play, is there?

comment.author: 26504183@N07
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/swordscookie] well yes that is obvious .. I'm talking in a means of style .. on first appearance

comment.author: 53760844@N08
comment.authorname: bolerophoto — very slow in that moment

comment.author: 46650209@N07
comment._content:
And no doubt the overalls are covering his normal every day clothes, with mandatory collar and tie, and he wouldn't have been seen dead outside his place of work in overalls, just like my great grandfather, a plumber on the LMS railway in Scotland: he used to take his denim dungarees to work with him, wrapped in brown paper, and put them on there.
Here's a photo of him working in his own garden in the mid 30s, tie and all.
[http://www.flickr.com/photos/patrick_castelli/6928170995/]
